sense.name: a planned, complex activity with an objective
sense.commentary: OPERATION[+activity][+mission][+specific] Note: often a one-time event
sense.examples: John served in Operation Desert Storm. Humanitarian operations were halted due to the intense fighting. We watched the rescue operation live on television.

sense.name: precise calculation of numbers or data
sense.examples: That computer does millions of operations a second. Adding two and two is a simple arithmetic operation.

sense.name: general ability to perform or habitual behavior
sense.examples: The operation of these two espresso machines is not the same. John has been studying the brain's operation under different chemical stimulants. His smooth operation of the sailboat during a storm impressed the captain.

sense.name: a large-scale enterprise or business
sense.examples: This pharmaceutical firm's drug manufacturing has become a multinational operation. "Jack run's this whole operation" said Bill, sweeping his hand across the wide expanse of oil rigs.

sense.name: sequence of specific acts that comprise a form of work
sense.examples: The precise operations involved in making Chinese porcelain were unknown to Europeans. This diagram illustrates the machine tool's operations. He could perform the operation of changing a tire in his sleep.

sense.name: a state of being functional, valid, or in effect
sense.examples: The old textile mill is no longer in operation. These house rules are in operation until the end of the semester.

sense.name: a surgical procedure to repair a living body
sense.examples: Mary had an operation on her elbow last week. Thousands of bypass operations are performed each year. The race horse's operation was successful.
